@graph.title: Fractal patterns in nonlinear dynamics and applications
@graph.abstract: Cover -- Title Page -- Copyright Page -- Dedication -- Preface -- Table of Contents -- Preface -- Symbols -- 1: Scaling, Scale-invariance and Self-similarity -- 1.1 Dimensions of physical quantity -- 1.2 Buckingham Pi-theorem -- 1.3 Examples to illustrate the significance of Π-theorem -- 1.4 Similarity -- 1.5 Self-similarity -- 1.6 Dynamic scaling -- 1.7 Scale-invariance: Homogeneous function -- 1.7.1 Scale invariance: Generalized homogeneous functions -- 1.7.2 Dimension functions are scale-invariant -- 1.8 Power-law distribution -- 1.8.1 Examples of power-law distributions -- 1.8.1.1 Euclidean geometry -- 1.8.1.2 First return probability -- 1.8.2 Extensive numerical simulation to verify powerlaw first return probability -- 2: Fractals -- 2.1 Introduction -- 2.2 Euclidean geometry -- 2.3 Fractals -- 2.3.1 Recursive Cantor set -- 2.3.2 von Koch curve -- 2.3.3 Sierpinski gasket -- 2.4 Space of fractal -- 2.4.1 Complete metric space -- 2.4.2 Banach contraction mapping -- 2.4.3 Completeness of the fractal space -- 2.5 Construction of deterministic fractals -- 2.5.1 Iterated function system -- 3: Stochastic Fractal -- 3.1 Introduction -- 3.2 A brief description of stochastic process -- 3.3 Dyadic Cantor Set (DCS): Random fractal -- 3.4 Kinetic dyadic Cantor set -- 3.5 Stochastic dyadic Cantor set -- 3.6 Numerical simulation -- 3.7 Stochastic fractal in aggregation with stochastic self-replication -- 3.8 Discussion and summary -- 4: Multifractality -- 4.1 Introduction -- 4.2 The Legendre transformation -- 4.3 Theory of multifractality -- 4.3.0.1 Properties of the mass exponent τ(q) -- 4.3.1 Legendre transformation of τs(q):
